defs.docs: Board support crate for the STM32F3DISCOVERY

attributes.value: ! Board support crate for the STM32F3DISCOVERY
! $ # if you don't have the clone subcommand
! # flash and debug the "Hello, world" example
! You'll need to have both OpenOCD and arm-none-eabi-gcc installed.
! - Building an application that depends on this crate
! To build applications (binary crates) using this crate follow [cortex-m-quickstart] instructions
! and add this crate as a dependency in step number 6 and make sure you enable the "rt" Cargo
! feature of this crate. Also, instead of step number 4 remove *both* the build.rs and memory.x

defs.name: examples
defs.docs: Examples in order of increasing complexity

attributes.value: ! Examples in order of increasing complexity

defs.name: _00_hello
defs.docs: Prints "Hello, world" on the OpenOCD console

attributes.value: ! Prints "Hello, world" on the OpenOCD console

defs.name: _01_itm
defs.docs: Sends "Hello, world!" through the first ITM stimulus port

attributes.value: ! Sends "Hello, world!" through the first ITM stimulus port
! To receive the message on the host you'll have to do three things:
! You'll need to uncomment lines 8 and 15 of the `.gdbinit` file.
! You'll also need to connect the SWO pin of the on-board SWD programmer to pin PB3 as shown
! Finally, you'll need to run `itmdump itm.fifo` (mind the file paths) to receive the message.
! Read the documentation of the [`itm`] crate, which provides the `itmdump` tool,  for details.

defs.name: _02_leds
defs.docs: Turns all the user LEDs on

attributes.value: ! Turns all the user LEDs on
!     // clock configuration using the default settings (all clocks run at 8 MHz)
!     // TRY this alternate clock configuration (all clocks run at 16 MHz)
!     // clock configuration using the default settings (all clocks run at 8 MHz)
!     // TRY this alternate clock configuration (all clocks run at 16 MHz)
! This example requires you to short (connect) the TX and RX pins.
!     // clock configuration using the default settings (all clocks run at 8 MHz)
!     // TRY this alternate clock configuration (clocks run at nearly the maximum frequency)
!     // The Serial API is highly generic
!     // TRY the commented out, different pin configurations
!     // TRY using a different USART peripheral here
!     let serial = Serial::usart1(p.USART1, (tx, rx), 9_600.bps(), clocks, &mut rcc.apb2);
!     // The `block!` macro makes an operation block until it finishes
!     // if all goes well you should reach this breakpoint
! In this example every received byte will be sent back to the sender. You can test this example
!     let serial = Serial::usart1(p.USART1, (tx, rx), 115_200.bps(), clocks, &mut rcc.apb2);
!     // The `L3gd20` abstraction exposed by the `f3` crate requires a specific pin configuration to
!     // be used and won't accept any configuration other than the one used here. Trying to use a
!     // different pin configuration will result in a compiler error.
!     // sanity check: the WHO_AM_I register always contains this value
!     // when you reach this breakpoint you'll be able to inspect the variable `_m` which contains the
!     // gyroscope and the temperature sensor readings
!     // The `Lsm303dlhc` abstraction exposed by the `f3` crate requires a specific pin configuration
!     // to be used and won't accept any configuration other than the one used here. Trying to use a
!     // different pin configuration will result in a compiler error.
!     let i2c = I2c::i2c1(p.I2C1, (scl, sda), 400.khz(), clocks, &mut rcc.apb1);
!     // when you reach this breakpoint you'll be able to inspect the variables `_accel`, `_mag` and
!     // `_temp` which contain the accelerometer, compass (magnetometer) and temperature sensor

defs.name: _09_log_sensors
defs.docs: Logs data from the motion sensors over ITM

attributes.value: ! Logs data from the motion sensors over ITM
! This example logs sensor data over ITM. The data is encoded in a binary format and logged as
! COBS frames. The binary format is as follows:
! The suggested way to receive this data is to connect the F3 SWO pin to a UART to USB converter
! and then to read out the associated device file using `itmdump`. Make sure you configure the
! serial device before calling `itmdump`. The commands to run are:
! You can plot this data using the `plot.py` script in the root of this crate.
! // TRY changing the number of samples
!     // TODO this should be some high level API in the cortex-m crate
!         // STM32 specific: enable tracing in the DBGMCU_CR register
!     let i2c = I2c::i2c1(dp.I2C1, (scl, sda), 400.khz(), clocks, &mut rcc.apb1);
!     let mut timer = Timer::tim2(dp.TIM2, FREQUENCY.hz(), clocks, &mut rcc.apb1);
! This demo runs Madgwick's orientation filter and logs the orientation of the board as
! quaternions via the ITM. The data is encoded in binary format and logged as COBS frame. The
! where the quaternion is the tuple `(w, x, y, z)`
! The suggested way to receive this data is to connect the F3 SWO pin to a UART to USB converter
! and then to read out the associated device file using `itmdump`. Make sure you configure the
! serial device before calling `itmdump`. The commands to run are:
! You can pipe the quaternions through the `viz` program (shipped with this crate) to get real
! time [visualization]. The command to run is:
! // Number of samples to use for gyroscope calibration
! // NOTE you need to use the right parameters for *your* magnetometer
! // You can use the `log-sensors` example to calibrate your magnetometer. The producer is explained
! // Sensitivities of the accelerometer and gyroscope, respectively
! const K_AR: f32 = 8.75e-3 * PI / 180.; // LSB -> rad/s
!     // TODO this should be some high level API in the cortex-m crate
!         // STM32 specific: enable tracing in the DBGMCU_CR register
!     let i2c = I2c::i2c1(dp.I2C1, (scl, sda), 400.khz(), clocks, &mut rcc.apb1);
!     let mut timer = Timer::tim2(dp.TIM2, 380.hz(), clocks, &mut rcc.apb1);
!     // Turn on the LED after calibrating the gyroscope
!     let mut timer = Timer::tim2(timer.free(), SAMPLE_FREQ.hz(), clocks, &mut rcc.apb1);
!         // Fix the X Y Z components of the magnetometer so they match the gyro axes
!         // Fix the X Y Z components of the accelerometer so they match the gyro axes
